title-group.article-title: The impact of various policy factors implemented for controlling the spread of COVID-19

contrib-group.aff: aRMK College of Engineering and Technology, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India
bSRM Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India

license.license-p: Since January 2020 Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The COVID-19 resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier hereby grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research that is available on the COVID-19 resource centre - including this research content - immediately available in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analyses in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. These permissions are granted for free by Elsevier for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active.

abstract.p: More than sixty million cases were affected by the novel corona virus around the world till date. The virus has reached more than 200 countries and more than seven lakh people have lost their lives globally so far. To control the spread of this virus many countries have taken extreme measures but still couldn’t control the spread. The primary objective of this analysis is to classify the various policy factors adopted by the countries to manage the spread of Covid-19. Our study uses Oxford Covid-19 Government Response Tracker (OxCGRT) dataset and Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model as the model for forecasting. The representation is trained using day wise number of infected cases reported in each country from August’2020 to October’2020 and then forecasts the number of infections for five days from 15th November’ 2020 to 19th November’2020. We have included 15 countries in our study and analysed 13 factors which includes 8 factors in Containment and Closure policies category, 2 factors in Economic policies category and 3 factors in Health System policies category. We analysed the impact of above factors by comparing the forecasted number of affected people with the actual total diseased cases reported in those five days. The study discovers the fact that out of thirteen policy factors, the countries which concentrated more on policies in economic category during the pandemic have helped in controlling the dissemination of covid-19.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In December 2019 and January2020, the original cases of the novel corona virus (2019-nCoV) occurred in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. About the average age at diagnosis among the initial 425 patients with reported novel corona virus was 59 years and 56% of them were masculine. The plurality of cases, compared to 8.6 percent of subsequent cases (55 percent) reported before January 2020 was related to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Industry. The novel corona virus SARS-CoV-2 the infection was called as “COVID-19” On January30, the World Health Organisation (WHO) announced the epidemic of COVID-19 to constitute a WHO state of emergency of international significance Director-General [1]. Corona virus also known publicly being known as SARS-CoV-2, publicly named as COVID-19 by the World Health Organization (WHO) [2]. Currently many countries are trying to produce a medicine to treat covid-19 but till now no medicine has globally accepted for treating covid-19. This pandemic situation has opened new challenges for the researchers around the globe. In order to reliably predict machine learning models, the spread of virus and such forecast also helps to infer the trends and patterns in the virus spread. Partial Derivative Regression and Nonlinear Machine Learning (PDR-NML) method predicts the Covid-19 outbreak with reasonable accuracy [3].

Among a large array of methods of machine learning, the adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) and Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average Model (ARIMA) models showed promising results [4], [5], [6]. Other benchmark forecasting techniques, such as linear regression (LR), support vector machine (SVM), and exponential smoothing (ES) are utilized for forecasting the threatening factors of virus spread [11]. Machine learning mechanism including hidden Markov chain model (HMM) and long-short-term-memory model (LSTM) are best suited models for short term predictions [7]. XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) [8] is a supervised machine learning method based on a gradient tree that can execute both classification and regression problems. The positive instances can be given as input to the XGBoost regression model which gives the number documented instances of COVID-19 in a nation as response [9]. The mixture machine learning model using adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) and multi-layered perceptron-imperialist competitive algorithm (MLP-ICA) were used to predict infected cases in time series and death rate in each country [10]. The performance of each of forecasting models can be evaluated in terms of R-squared (R2) score, Adjusted R-Square (R2 adjusted), mean square error (MSE), mean absolute error (MAE) and root mean square error (RMSE) [11]. The key purpose of our paper is to examine the effect of different policy factors that government authorities have taken to monitor the spread of the new corona virus. The SIR models are based on the understanding technique of how rapidly individuals switch between three major states: persons are either vulnerable towards the virus (S); have been corrupted (I); and then heal (R) or pass away. A team led by theoretical infectious disease specialist Sunetra Gupta at the University of Oxford, UK, has indicated that the trend of recent UK fatality may suit a variety of SIR models, counting the one with the intention of assumes which millions of individuals have also been affected but have not shown any symptoms [15]. Lasso The model performs a regression analysis that calculates the strength of the relationship between a specific measure such as school closure and a metric R that measures the average number of individuals diagnosed by each infected person. Using Lasso, Scientists may decide which actions reduce R most [16]. The independent SEIR-type model, which utilizes predictive analytics, piecewise continuous touch rate function, diagnostic rate and individual actions, shows that integrating predictive analytics with a mathematical formula is useful to explain the complexities of the outbreak from the beginning stage and to calculate the basic impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions, together with lockout, medical assistance and media [17]. A 60% decrease in transmission through quarantining would regulate dissemination within one day of symptom initiation is simple to suggest, but it is unknown what coping mechanisms or social distancing behaviour people and policymakers need to put in order to accomplish the desired. [18].

sec.title: Method
sec.p: For building the forecasting model we used Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model which is a mixture of Autoregressive (AR) model and Moving Average (MA) model. In Autoregressive model, the variable of notice is forecasted using the past value of the same variable [12]. The term Auto-regression point to that it is regression on the variable itself. The auto-regressive model of order ‘q’ is represented as ∅Zt=c+∅1Zt -1+∅2Zt -2+·.·.·.·+∅qZt - q+∈t
q = Order of Autoregressive Regression division
e = the degree of initial differentiation involved
r = the moving average division order

Moving Average (MA) Instead of using prior values of the predicted variable in a regression, the algorithm uses previous estimation errors. [13]. The Moving Average model is represented asZt=c+∈t+θ1∈t -1+θ2+∈t -2+·.·.·.·+θr∈t - r
In ARIMA model, the differencing with Auto-regression and a Moving Average

sec.title: Dataset
sec.p:
We used the Covid-19 datasets gathered from Oxford COVID-19 Government Response Tracker (OxCGRT) which offers organized way for tracking Ministerial responses to COVID-19 crosswise countries and time [14]. The Government Response Tracker systematically collects day wise Covid-19 number reported cases, number of reported deaths and also gathers data on several different pieces of information general policy responses that each country have taken to react the spread of virus. The policy responses considered in our study are categorised into three categories i.e., Policies for Isolation and Closures (Table 1
), Financial policies (Table 2
) and Policies in the Health Sector (Table 3
).Table 1
Policies for isolation and closures.
S. NoNameDescriptionValues
1C1_School closingRecord shutdowns of colleges and schools0 - no measurements1 - Suggest to close2 - Closing needed3 - Closing all levels is importantNull - no details
2C2_Work environment closingRecord workplace closings0 - no measurements1 - Suggest to close (or recommend work from home)2 - Closing needed3 - For all but necessary workplaces, closure needsBlank - no data
3C3_ Public Activities CancelDocument cancellation of public programmes0 - no measurements1 - Propose cancellation of the2 - Cancellation neededNull - no details
4C4-Restrictions for meetingsRecord limitations on private meetings0 - no constraints1 - limits on very big gatherings (the boundary is above 1000 people)2 - limits on gatherings of 101–1000 individuals3 - limits on meetings among 11–100 individuals4 - limits on groups of ten or less peopleNull - no details
5C5_ Near public transit linksClose connection to public transport0 - no measurements1 - Suggest to close2 - Closing neededNull - no details
6C6_ Stay with home specificationsRecord “shelter-in-place” instructions and otherwise confine them to the house.0 - no measurements1 - Advise not to go away the house2 - Do not leave home except for regular work out, grocery shopping and ‘key’ trips.3 - do not leave the house, with minimal exceptions (eg Required to leave once a week, or can leave just one person at a time, etc)Null - no details
7C7_Internal restrictions on travelDocument internal travel restrictions between urban centers0 - no measurements1 - Suggest not moving between regions or cities2 - internal limits on travel in placeNull - no details
8C8_ Foreign restrictions on travelRecord Global Travel Limitations0 - no constraints1 - Arrival screening2 - arrivals in quarantine from any or all area3 - bar arrivals starting certain areas4 - ban on all areas or complete closure of bordersNull - no detailsTable 2
Financial policies.
S. NoNameDescriptionValues
1E1_Revenue supportDocument if the government is providing direct cash Payments of persons that are losing their jobs or are unable to work.0 - no revenue support1 - Less than 50 percent of missed salaries are absorbed by the state.2 -Government replacements for 50 percent or more of missing incomeBlank - no data
2E2_Debt/contract reliefRecord if the government is freezing financial obligations for households0 - no debt/contract relief1 - narrow relief, unique to one form of agreement2 - Broad debt/relief of contractsTable 3
Policies in the health sector.
S. NoNameDescriptionCoding
1H1_ Campaigns for public informationRecords of public awareness campaigns0 - no Covid-19 campaign for public information1 - community officials calling for carefulness in respect of Covid-19–192 - concerted drive for public informationNull - no details
2H2_ Policy testingRecord policy by the government on who has rights to research0 - no testing policy for testing1 - only those who have all (a) symptoms AND (b) satisfy clear requirements2 - examination of those displaying signs of Covid-193 - Free research by the public (eg “drive through” on-hand monitoring for asymptomatic persons)Null - no details
3H3_ Tracing contactRecord government policy on tracing connections following a promising diagnosis0 - no touch tracing1 - limited touch tracing; not performed in all cases2 - thorough get in touch with tracing; performed for all cases found

Day wise number of infected cases, number of confirmed deaths, government responses of all factors in controlling the spread of virus is included in the time series data. The government responses for each factors are collected in ordinal scale value ranging from 0 to 4 where 0 - no response, 1 - less response, 2 - average response, 3 - good response, 4 - excellent response.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
We developed the ARIMA model using OxCGRT dataset and used the number of infections reported from August’2020 to October’2020. Furthermore, the ARIMA model is used to predict the number of illnesses from 15th November’2020 to 19th November’2020 (Fig. 1
) in fifteen countries which we have included in our study. The amount of infections expected is compared with the real infected cases identified in each of the 15 countries. If the number of actual infections is less than the predicted number of infections then it implies that measures taken by the concern Government has helped in controlling the spread of virus. To prove our argument we compared the actual number of infections with predicted number of infections and we have computed the mean of each policy measures taken by the Government (Table 4, Table 5, Table 6, Table 7
). Since we have the taken infections data from August’2020 to October’2020, the policy factors in three categories (Economic policies, Confinement and Termination policies, Health Sector policies) during that period are considered.Fig. 1

Regarding policy factors in Containment - closure category & Health System category, almost all countries have taken some measures. The countries namely Belgium, Switzerland, Ireland, Bahrain, Oman, Singapore, Iceland & Qatar have actively implemented the economic policy by providing straight cash payments to the pe ople who nowhere to be found their jobs or cannot work. Through estimating the expected number of infected patients with the actual number of infected patients in those countries, we may conclude the positive effect of such interventions. The actual number of cases reported is lower than the expected number of cases, which indicate that, the economic policy measures adopted by the respective government authorities, especially during the month of October, helped to control the spread of cases. Countries like Japan, Kuwait, South Korea, Mexico, Indonesia, Philippines and Palestine haven’t implemented the economic policy effectively by providing such direct payments to their people. The total number of infection cases within these countries is larger than the estimated number of infected cases. This shows that other measures taken by the Government couldn’t effectively control the spread.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Various countries have taken different measures to monitor dissemination of covid-19 but only few countries have succeeded in monitoring the spread of virus. In our study, we have included 15 countries and evaluated the various policy factors implemented by respective Government authorities to control the spread of virus. The ARIMA model uses the dataset with number of reported daily infections during August, September & October month and then the number of infected cases after fourteen days has been forecasted. Using the result we analysed all the policy factors categorised in Containment & Closure policy, Health System policy and Economic Policy category. We found that almost all the countries have taken some measures in Containment & Closure policy category and Health System policy category. And interestingly we found that those countries which have given more than 50% of salary to the people directly who either lost their job or cannot work have resulted in controlling the spread. Those countries which haven’t taken such measures effectively couldn’t control the spread. In future we will try to build a mathematical model for identifying the impact of various policy factors in to monitor the spread of covid-19.

sec.title: CRediT authorship contribution statement
sec.p: P.N. Senthil Prakash: Conceptualization, Data curation. B. Hariharan: Formal analysis, Methodology, Writing - review & editing. S. Kaliraj: Project administration, Writing - original draft. R. Siva: Supervision, Validation. D. Vivek: Funding acquisition.

sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
